column1: Krimpen aan den IJssel (Dutch pronunciation: [ˈkrɪmpə(n) aːn dɛn ˈɛisəl] (listen)) is a town and municipality in the western Netherlands
column2: in the province of South Holland. The municipality had a population of 29
column4: and covers an area of 8.95 km2 (3.46 sq mi) of which 1.26 km2 (0.49 sq mi) is water.

column1: == History ==
Krimpen is first mentioned in a document from 1277. Like other hamlets
column2: many different spellings of its name have occurred over time
column3: among which the name Tingenijssel deviated the most from today's spelling. The municipality is on the south shore of the river Hollandse IJssel. For many centuries
column4: the only buildings in Krimpen were farm houses built along the river dike. They formed more or less autonomous communities along the dike.

column1: Before the 20th century
column2: the two principal industrial employers were the brick factory Mijnlieff and the shipyard Van der Giessen de Noord.

column1: In the beginning of the 20th century development began inland from the river dikes
column2: and the municipality began to lose its agricultural character.

column1: During the North Sea flood of 1953
column2: the tidal barrier in the river IJssel proved to be inadequate. So in 1954 construction started on a new storm surge barrier
column3: the first installation of the Delta Works.

column1: In 1958 it was completed together with the Algera Bridge which connects Krimpen with Capelle aan den IJssel.
In the mid 1960s
column2: Krimpen became a commuter town for people working in Rotterdam
column3: resulting in major expansion. Today most of the municipality has been built up
column4: except for the Krimpenerwaard where the town council aims to retain the rural character.
